did.unittitle: Benjamin Franklin Papers Part 4 -- Letters to Franklin
did.abstract:
This is part of the large inventory for the Benjamin Franklin Papers (Mss B F85). For complete information concerning this collection, please view the
Collection Description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The reply of the States-General to the memoir of France; in case they refuse to agree to France's terms, the King will exclude them from the regulations in favor of neutral nations. Sir Joseph Yorke's influence with a certain great personage. Splendid part played by their friend [M. Van Berkel].
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has written to General Arnold to grant him, in consideration of the name he bears, employment in the American army; is thirty-eight years old and the father of a numerous family; desires Franklin to lend his influence to the request.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The "Chasseur" loaded and only waiting for the "Governor Livingston," which is detained by contrary winds at Isle de Ré; glad a convoy is appointed. Continued advices of captures have stagnated all private expeditions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accusation against one M. le Ralle, who is probably in hiding at Paris, and who, among his other crimes, borrowed ten Louis from him which he never returned; thinks he may seek Franklin's protection, and so forewarns him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The protection and assistance he rendered to Americans in Ireland, particularly Colonel Ethan Allen and those who were with him. Desires a license to remain in Marseilles with his two sons and their Swiss tutor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Transmitting an Act of Congress of the 23d ult.; quotes from the Secretary's letter to explain who Mr. Gosrunus Erkelens is and the nature of his occupation; encloses a copy of an Act of Congress of the 1st inst. on the subject of an expedition against Canada.
(In triplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter, received the day before, from Dr. Berkenbout; wishes to know if anything can be made of it for the public good.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desired by Messrs. Jacob Hagen and Son, of London, to enclose the following copy of a Resolution of the Pennsylvania Land Co.

Enclosure. A Resolution to propose to the Governors of the pennsylvania Hospital to receive from the Pennsylvania Land Co. as much of their remaining property in America as may be deemed a reasonable equivalent for the sum due them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notification of bills of exchange furnished to the Continental Loan Office of Massachusetts Bay.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In his letter of November, 1777, acquainted Franklin with the death of Mrs. Bache, of Preston; is very anxious for news of Franklin and his family.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Du Bouchet, Denis-Jean-Florimond de Langlois de Mautheville, chevalier. Auxerre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishing Franklin every happiness and prosperity. Desires any news he may have received of General Conway.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In consequence of the numerous prizes sold at Brest, various articles can be bought for the United States at advantageous prices; offers to transact these purchases.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him Faujas de Saint-Fond's "Recherches sur les volcano Éteints du Vivarais et du Velay," for which he subscribed.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Speaks of the Marquis de la Fayette in the most complimentary manner. Commends Count d'Estaing highly, and explains the cause for the ungrounded prejudice against him; the peaceable, inoffensive and courteous behaviour of his men. Proposed invasion of Canada.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks Franklin for his kindness to M. Briffant who has been well recieved in Boston and asks that the enclosed letter be forwarded to him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Precautions taken before recommending M. Jean de Neufville to Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of Comte d'Estaing and his fleet. Damage sustained by Admiral Byron's fleet during a storm. Capture of the Island of St. Lucia by the English; the expedition against them of Comte d'Estaing, and its ignominious failure, owing to the Comte's weakness and cowardice. Encloses an extract of a letter to M. de Sartine from the Governor of Guadeloupe, on behalf of the owners and crew of an American privateer which was unfortunately sunk by one of the batteries of that island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Franklin to forward the enclosed letter.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing his son to Franklin, and asking him to afford the young man his patronage and advice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a list of certain articles which he offers to procure for the United States. Details relative to the sale of "La Revanche."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a new quality of beer and its various excellencies.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John Lloyd, et al., Merchants. Nantes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complaining of lack of protection to American vessels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just procured an inventory of the sale of the two ships; believes that the larger of the two vessels will be suitable to Franklin's purpose, as well as the cargo of merchandise.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing the Baron Sturler de l'Altemberg.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him to obtain his deliverance from prison so as to enter the service of the United States.
(In French.)
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A Lutheran clergyman with a large family, desires to go to America and earn his living. Has supported his family by teaching, preaching and writing books. Wishes to know whether he can make a support by teaching writing or farming in America; if these are impossible, suggests aiding the American army by his knowledge of strategy.
(In Latin.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of his son who has been a prisoner in Portsmouth Jail for several months; begs Franklin to procure his exchange and, if possible, send him home in some public vessel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the depreciation of the currency and the consequent high prices. Danger of contracting debts in the present reduced state of the paper credit. Possibility of France advancing a sufficient sum to sink the Continental paper. Aid he has given to two Americans who were wounded in an engagement with an English privateer. The "Governor Livingston" and the "Chasseur" almost ready to sail.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends copies of General Washington's letter, testifying to his good character, also his congé from General Gates; joins to this his general essay on the Prossian Tactics which he proposed to General Washington when he found that the American officers were in need of learning their métier.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for his favor received by Mr. Wharton, as well as for the articles therein mentioned. According to his advice, has written to Mrs. Mecom for directions how to make crown soap.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Montboissier, Philippe-Claude de Beaufort-Canillac, comte de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of his promise to give a letter of recommendation to M. Fleurian de Langle, a relative of the Marquis de la Fayette.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the articles manufactured in his iron foundry, and the prices.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Affairs in Holland; quotes an explanation of France's memoir, sent to the Grand Pensionnaire by the French Ambassador.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His project of going to America checked; one of the richest ships to his address has been blown up; every soul perished and not a farthing saved; loss sustained by M. de Chaumont and M. de Montieu.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Assurance of the continued love and esteem of the members of their Society for Dr. Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explaining a project of himself and a friend to go to America and engage in commerce at first, and later in agriculture; begs Franklin to give them his advice, and if possible, facilitate their passage over.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the burning of the ship "le Flaman," Captain Blondeau. Has written many times requesting answers to his letters he brought from the Governor of Virginia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers to send woolen clothes to the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his letter of the 25th ult. Containing the approval of his proposition; unfortunately, before its receipt, the ship intended for the voyage was sold at public auction; his regret at such a miscarriage of his plans. His intended trip to Stockholm; is aware that America does not need the good will of any more European powers, but nothing ought to be neglected. Mr. F. Lewis has promised his utmost interest to get him some employment in Europe; his present character that of a modern Don Quixote.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning an order by Franklin, to pay a certain sum to a young man, named Colomb de Nismes, at present in a Savannish regiment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His Mecca is to see Franklin in Holland, consummating the work begun by himself.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: D' Arbaud, Helle Comte. Basse Terre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regarding the indemnification demanded for the owner and crew of the "Fair Play."
(Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging F[rankli]n to procure for the bearer, Mr. Morris, access to the persons he wants to see; his business is to procure some passports; trusts this will give Dr. Franklin small trouble. Sends the enclosed papers by Mr. Morris, of their contents he is ignorant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Undaunted by the cruelty of the English toward French prisoners, desires to fight under the colors of liberty; begs for an interview so that, should his request be refused, he may still have seen the most illustrious man of his age.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the two prizes taken by him since he left Brest; the Court of Admiralty's failure to condemn the cargo of the second prize.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: By a memoir just presented, Holland is excluded from all the favors which France grants to neutral nations; Amsterdam alone to be left in enjoyment of these; great discontent prevails.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends Franklin two of his chapters; takes the liberty of keeping the third for himself. Impatiently awaiting the arrival of M. de Montieu.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Orders from the King of Spain to admit American corsairs and their prizes to the port of Alicante; necessity of having a consul-general there to look after American interests; offers himself for the position.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing à memorandum of the sale of two small prizes. Informing Franklin of some excellent beer and rum which he can purchase.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John Watson and John Swain. Calais

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acquainting them with their capture, by the English, in October, 1777, their subsequent escape, and present confinement in Calais prison; their destitute condition and desire to obtain their freedom in order to reënter the American service.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing Franklin that the affair of Captain Macknil [McNeill] has been tried and settled in the Captain's favor.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has sent him a copy of his work "Dissertation Chimique sur leseaux minérales de la Lorraine"; stimulating effect on his own work of Franklin's treatise on electricity. Has discovered a sure process of dyeing cottons a fast black; offers to treat with Franklin concerning this discovery, if it can be of use to America.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Blancherie, Claude-Mammès de Pahin Champlain de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends Franklin the new plan of the institution of which he is the head; invites Franklin, his grandson and Dr. Adams to the first meeting, to be held on the 20th inst.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At the request of Prince Gallitzin, sends him a letter, concerning some experiments in electricity.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to communicate the contents of the enclosed to his colleagues, particularly to Mr. Izard.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The 26th of January appointed by the King of France for the publication of the new regulations, In case he does not receive a suitable reply from Holland before that time; irresolution in the Holland Assembly; courier sent to France to request a week's delay; attitude of Amsterdam.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to pay no attention to an open letter which may be presented to him by a M. Poirier, a lawyer of Dunkirk; his reasons for doubting the good faith of this gentleman; his desire to obtain the position of American agent at Dunkirk; is sending Franklin four lines by the hand of a much better friend to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copy of discharge given to William Gardner an American prisoner on board the British warship, "Lenox."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is quite sure that he left the papers containing the Resolves of Congress in Franklin's book at Passy, after he had finished the copy for Mr. Lee; if they are not to be found will send Franklin a fair copy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Having heard that Franklin was pleased with his samples of two colored cloths, offers him the fruits of his labors. Encloses a letter for Mr. Williams.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know if Franklin has conferred with his colleagues respecting the papers he sent him and their decision.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Calls upon Franklin to fulfil his promise, made in the presence of Lee and Adams, to send him a copy of his answer to the writer's letter of the 2d inst.; desires at the same time all his reasons, in writing, for disobeying the Resolution of Congress of May 7th, 1778.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Capellen tot den Pol, Joan Derk van der

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Despairs of making any progress in favor of American credit, while false reports of English victories are being continually circulated; urges the wisdom of having a correspondent devoted to the interests of France and America, to whom authentic reports might be forwarded. Favorable impression created by Governor Trumbull's letter. Appreciates the honor done him by the Ministers at Passy, in their generous commendation of his conduct with regard to the Scottish Brigade; thanks them for their very kind offer, which at present he is unable to accept. Excellent choice France has made in the person of the Duc de la Vauguyon.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lloyd, John et al. American Merchants at Nantes. Nantes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a convoy to guard merchant ships to America. Severity of weather hinders sailing of ships. Acknowledge receipt of a copy of the Treaty of Commerce, and ask what ports are to be free, pursuant to the 30th Article. Refer to danger from Barbary corsairs, and ask advice as to protection from them. Pray for more knowledge as to the impost duties levied by each of the United States. Patience and perseverance will win the present contest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes for information concerning a sum of money deposited in the public treasury, at Charleston, and redeemable at a certain date.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The mortification of their refusal to accept his bill; there is one method still left by which he may raise the desired sum; that is, for them to endorse a bill drawn by him on the President of Congress; if this suggestion is also refused, is afraid it will be attributed to their indifference to the fate of an American officer. Complains bitterly of the treatment he has received; exonerates Congress from being privy to it; hints at a time coming when he may be able to resent this treatment in another way than by words.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: George Hakins, John Tomling, James Horel, John Redaway and John Sheay. Quimper

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their escape from a British privateer and their present imprisonment among a parcel of French thieves, with only six sons a day to live upon, to lie on dirt at night, and to gaze through iron bars all day; beg Franklin to take pity on his poor countrymen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was appointed gunner on the brig "Lexington." Lost a leg while on that vessel. Has been in the Royal Marine Hospital at Brest. Is now cured from the effects of an operation. Wishes to proceed to America and requests a passage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin a poem which he trusts will meet with his approbation. Desires to know if the "Société d'Emulation," of London, rewards discoveries presented by any but Englishmen; the discovery in question will considerably shorten long and difficult calculations in weights, measures, monies, etc.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Criticised for her informal relations with Franklin; necessary to submit to what is called propriety. State of her nerves; begs him to drink tea with her every day.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was captured by a Jersey privateer whose captain accidentally let fall that Mr. Dobrée, of Guernsey, was one of his owners; his son, Mr. Dobree of Nantes, anxious to have in writing the particulars of this conversation, but as it is a matter which concerns the country, thought it best to leave the decision with them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: For his sentiments, refers Franklin to his letters written as a Member of Parliament to his constituents. The alliance between France and the United States is an obstacle to peace.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, VIII, 312; Bigelow, VI, 296).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning some property belonging to Mr.Simeon Deane which was delivered by mistake to M.Schweighauser. Bill for gunstocks, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting the Commissioners to obtain articles of war for the State of Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Demands justice from Franklin in the case of one of his compatriots, who hired a chaise from him on the pretext of going to Paris to consult him on important business; since then nothing has been heard of the chaise.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has communicated Franklin's favor of January 1st to the Board of Sick and Hurt and received their answer to the effect that measures are being taken to send to France the number of Americans agreed upon for the exchange.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting passes for certain American ships which otherwise are taken by their own people as well as by the enemy. Reports received from Cadiz of an engagement between Comte d'Estaing and an English fleet. Letters from Martinique mention that their ports are blockaded by English cruisers and that Comte d'Estaing is daily expected.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Upon hearing that there are 5,000 officers without employment in America, gave up an idea of bearing arms there. Is very anxious to join a friend of his in Boston; desires to know something about that city, if a man can live there pleasantly and if the price of provisions are very high.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Implores Dr. Franklin to procure his freedom, that he might secure a pass and proceed to his family in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to obtain his release.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complains that five of his sailors have deserted, and have then been taken on board French privateers. Has been involved in five law-suits; considers one which he lost very unjust, whereby he is forced to pay his sailors' debts, after he had notified the people that he would not be answerable for their debts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a loan for the United States to be raised at Amsterdam; his dissatisfaction with the manner in which the affair has been conducted. Greater work he could accomplish if he had a formal commission as American Chargé d' Affaires to the United Netherlands.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Pierre le Cacheur, Julien Bertols, ----- Farcis, and ----- Vincent

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ask Franklin to obtain their liberty so as to enable them to enter the service of the United States.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Blancherie, Claude-Mammès de Pahin Champlain de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Missed him at the last meeting; hopes he may have the pleasure of seeing him at the next.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was unable to see Mr. Lee, on account of his being ill. His miserable situation without money or friends; his family unable to assist him; anchors all his hopes to Franklin; is only too anxious to serve America and revenge himself for all the ill treatment inflicted upon him by the enemy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His arrival from America via Havana. Has some letters to deliver to them in person; must first go to Nantes to give directions for the disposal of any property, belonging to South Carolina which has arrived in Europe.

did.unittitle: to Benjamin Franklin and J. Adams

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His fever still confines him to the house. Urges the absolute necessity of informing the Minister without delay of the exhausted state of their finances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His inability to either speak or understand French, and begs Dr. Franklin to procure his freedom and enable him to proceed to his family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His son entered the American service in January, 1777; in 1778, he was a lieutenant in the 4th Battalion of Georgia; since then has heard nothing; if he lives, begs Franklin to aid his advancement, and if he is dead, asks for a certificate of the fact.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging that the enclosed letter be sent to Philadelphia with Franklin's despatches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks his protection for two friends at Lyons; having received his permission to communicate their plans to him, sends the enclosed letter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Resolution of November 18th annulled by the Holland Assembly; their answer to France not yet decided upon.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks Franklin to assist his brother, to whom he gave one of the commissions of lieutenant, which the Congress of Georgia empowered him to bestow; has heard that le Sieur de Foucherelles has endeavored to injure his and his brother's reputation. Asks if it is true that Franklin discouraged M. Aubert from attempting another passage to Savannah.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to postpone his dinner with Mme. Bouffé from February 2d to the 3d or 10th.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning his right to vessels recaptured as prizes.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lloyd, John et al. American Merchants and Captains of Vessels. Nantes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complaining of the hindrances to American vessels in French waters, and asking for redress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sent Franklin three certificates of the supplies furnished in 1776 by M. Laframboise to the army of the United States at Three Rivers, in Canada; reminds Franklin of his promise to obtain, from Congress, the payment of this sum.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has need of his advice in a career which grows more and more ticklish.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending [I.] Bordot for the position of agent of Congress at La Rochelle.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Continental Congress, Committee of Foreign Affairs. Philadelphia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The enemy exerting their forces but too successfully in Georgia; hopes that Comte d'Estaing will be able to operate with the Colonial forces in order to wrest from their foes the fruits of their present success. Late as it is, encloses a quadruplicate of his credentials and wishes him every success in his important agency.
(Copy.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Continental Congress, Committee of Foreign Affairs. Philadelphia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Triplicate of preceding, with an additional letter announcing that he has forwarded, via St. Eustatia, letters for Franklin and the Marquis de la Fayette, from the President of Congress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was made prisoner when the vessel "Senaut Protée," from Philadelphia for France, was captured by two English privateers. Amongst his letters and papers seized were severed bills of exchange drawn on the American Commissioners. The latter are requested not to pay these bills, unless endosed by Hope and Co., of Amsterdam.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning two indorsements, by Arthur Lee, written on the back of his accounts sent to the Commissioners; quotes the two in full; considers them as injurious to his reputation as they are false and malignant; begs them to order an examination of his accounts; desires nothing but justice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Giving him a comb which will last another twenty years; believes he will have a long life.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning an expedition of which he is to be given the command; hopes it may take place as it will plague their good friends, and perhaps get some money for America; with two such points in view, would go round the world; is awaiting Captain Jones with the greatest impatience.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning prize vessels captured by Captain Pi[c]ker[i]n.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the arrival of a small English ship called the "Butterfly," captured on the 16th by the Corsair, "le Marquis de la Fayette."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of Captain Jason Lawrence, whose schooner, the "General Arnold," was captured by a Jersey privateer; he destroyed the packets and bills of exchange he had from Congress; he reports great unanimity in Pennsylvania and much spirit in Philadelphia; European goods scarce and dear; the English privateers off Chesapeake Bay very numerous.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him the letter written to himself and Mr. Adams in consequence of the accusations of Mr. Lee [XXXVII, 4, see p.17]. Concerning the choice of his judges; sends an estimate of the supplies which have passed through his hands and an estimate of his profits, which amounted to not 1 1/4 per cent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning some furs which he brought over to France from Boston; trouble with the custom house; desires Franklin to write them a line of explanation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notification of bills of exchange furnished to the States of Pennsylvania and New Jersey.
(In quadruplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing the two papers confided to him by Franklin; looked in vain for him at M. de la Blancherie's assemblies.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging their letter of the 26th ult., addressed to several American gentlemen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks that the enclosed letter concerning Mr.Parker's ship may be forwarded by a safe conveyance. Thinks Mr.Deane has been imprudent in the matter of his publications. The amazing damage done to the country by too much paper and too little hard money. Hopes the wisdom of Congress and the assistance of France will decrease the high price of all articles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of a brig from Edenton; Captain reports that troops were embarking at New York, that General Washington was moving to the north and General [Nathanael] Greene to the south.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking Franklin to return him the French verses which he gave him on the last occasion Franklin dined at his house.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Antonio Francesco Salucci et fils . Leghorn

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a vessel they have fitted out for America; thanks Franklin for the passport granted the captain and begs him to write to America in order to facilitate this project.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has accepted the command of a privateer at Dunkirk and desires a commission from Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is anxious to hear what success has attended Franklin's letter on his account, to the Congress of Georgia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sees that Mr. Deane, in his public letter, has declared that he received a Resolution of Congress recalling him and appointing another Commissioner in his place on the 4th of March; desires to know if this fact was concealed from Franklin as well as from him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Instances in which certain articles of the Treaty of Commerce have not been enforced. Report of a successful enterprise against Savannah, by a detachment of British troops who, it was said, were marching toward Charleston without opposition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the appointment of Dr. Bancroft to transact business for them in England; at a loss to conceive why he has no choice in this matter; the notorious character of Dr. Bancroft as a stock-jobber; his living in open defiance of decency and religion; his enmity against him [Lee]; has evidence in his possession proving Dr. Bancroft a criminal with regard to the United States; washes his hands of any such appointment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Would have delivered personally to Franklin the letter intrusted to him by General Gates, if his health had permitted it; lost his arm while commanding the "Cæsar" in an engagement off Rhode Island, and the wound is not yet healed; has entrusted the letter to M.de La Neuville, a great friend of General Gates.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: O’Heguerty, Peter Charles Daniel, count. Nancy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to offer his services to the Americans and begs for a letter of recommendation for that country; has a profession and a fortune, but detests idleness.
(In French).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing his arrival from Boston where he was fitted out for the purpose of conveying to France, the Marquis de la Fayette and his suite and the Chevalier de Raimondis. Difficulty they had in obtaining seamen owing to the number of privateer ships of war in America; describes a threatened mutiny on board and the instant means they took to check it; at present in need of 100 good seamen. Describes the trip. Thirty-eight of his men in irons.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to know if it is true that Dr.Bancroft goes to England, charged with a commission from Franklin, Adams and himself

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting his invitation to dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking them to procure his brother's discharge from prison at Dinan, as well as certain other prisoners who claim to go on board any ship-of -war belonging to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to his letters of the 15th and 25th of June with enclosure to General Washington with inquiries concerning Baron Hermann de Zedwitz, who owed him a considerable sum of money.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: No marks mentioned by which Mr.Deane's claim to any of the goods in the possession of the public agent can be ascertained; cannot think it consistent with his duty to concur in delivering them to any person upon so inadequate a claim.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Having heard that it is their intention to despatch some person to England to negotiate an exchange of prisoners, offers his services in that capacity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwards the letter just received; convinced that the gentleman who offers his services, is unexceptionable as to character and abilities; hopes he will meet with their approbation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the four passports for the ship.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the type ordered by Franklin, which is ready to be sent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Being now convinced that Mr. Deane's claim is ascertained by marks, has signed the letter, Reasons why he is unwilling to sign the letter to Captain Jones concerning his commission. Complains of having received a very indecent letter from Dr. Bancroft desiring a copy of the letter containing an attack upon his character; the disclosure of privately expressed opinions can only expose the Commissioners to abuse and malevolence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explains a glaring act of injustice to some American seamen by the Judge of the Admiralty; these men, having escaped from prison, entered into the service of an English vessel of which they afterwards gained possession; having arrived at Martinique and being fired on by the forts, they sought the protection of a French frigate who guided them into port; since then the Judge has condemed their ship as a lawful prize of the French frigate; the effect of such injustice on every American on this island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His plans for a National Academy of Education, a patriotic and philanthropic institution, the publication of a periodical Journal of Education, and the erection of a Hall of Fame.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating Franklin on his appointment as sole representative of America at the Court of France. Wishes to know if this "Alliance" is to return to America and if their fifteen or more vessels may have the benifit of her convoy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has written two letters explaining his miserable situation and begging for assistance, but has received no reply; lost everything when he was taken prisoner on the 19th of September, 1777.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Receipt for fifty Louis d'ors on account of public service to the United States which he undertook to perform.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The scepter of imposture is broken; the clarion note of philosophy has convicted Bernard and other dangerous snarlers, of lying and error; fearful effects of fanaticism; triumph of reason and humanity as exemplified in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The proceedings of Mr. Lee obliged him to assert his rights; this does not mean any lessening of his respect and admiration for Franklin.
(Press copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the summons sent his agent at Nantes, by order of the commissioners, to pay over the sum he received from the sale of the small cargo of "La Thèrese"; considers this sum as part payment of the immense amount due him from Congress. Goes over the many instances of his devotion to the American cause since the year 1776; the financial sacrifices he has made and the poor return he has had, culminating in this final proof of ingratitude. Has been falsely represented to Congress as deputed by the French Court to give outright the supplies sent over; owing to such insidious means his letters to Congress remained unanswered and no return was made for the cargoes, Is obliged to address this letter officially to the three Commissioners, but his personal resentment is directed only against Arthur Lee; his opinion of that gentleman's conduct. Pictures the results of an open breach over this affair; his own sources of retaliation.
(In French. Press copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Attested copy of a resolution ordering duplicates to be issued of bills of exchange, drawn in favor of Robert Bridges.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Deux-Ponts, Marianne Camasse (Gamache), comtesse de Forbach and duchesse douairière de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The long illness of her eldest son; her own collapse after the strain of nursing; her first pleasure is to write to Franklin; is sure of a place in his memory, which she guards with the utmost jealousy. Has received no news of her nephew; fears that he has been captured by the English; will not complain if he has died fighting for America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him many times for the good news received; is much better able to fight when Franklin supplies the weapons. Not necessary in future to sign their letters.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to have the two subjoined manuscripts printed, in order to promote a perpetual peace between America, England, and France.
(In French.)
A.E. by Franklin. "Project of universal peace by a galley-slave."

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Le Bolloche de Kerascoet, Ollivier-René . Paimpal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His eldest son, Thibault Le Bolloche, who sailed for America in June last, a prisoner at kilkenny, Ireland. Gives an account of himself, his family and children. Thanks Franklin for the kindness he has shown them, and begs him to advance his son two Louis to assist his return home.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging certain sums of money.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Apologizes for not waiting in person on Franklin with his humble request, but is obliged to leave at once for Lyons.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to make some improvements in physical apparatus. The new electrical machine be presented to Franklin is for sale, and can always be seen at the house of M. le Marquis de Courtanvaux; desires Franklin's approval of it.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning American seaman cast adrift at Lisbon, whose necessities have been relieved by the same gentleman mentioned in his letter of October 20th, 1778. Gives an account of a ship fitted out by this gentleman with a valuable cargo and manned with these American seamen; its subsequent capture by an English gun-ship the "Bellons." Enclose a list of the Americans now at the gentleman's house. Advisability of ordering a few French frigates to cruise off the harbor of Lisbon. Concerning a Mr. Bulkeley, who made his whole estate by the Americans and who is at present part owner of the English privateer, "Bellons."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: No answer yet to the French Ambassador.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Urges Franklin to hasten the examination of his accounts. Recommends Mr. Ridley as the bearer of Franklin's letters and despatches to America.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John Walsh and others. (English prisoners on board Patience.) Brest

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: While under the care and inspection of the officers of the " Ranger," experienced every attention and kindness, but since they have been in the charge of Mr. Riou, they have suffered various kinds of neglect; beg for a speedy exchange.
(Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. Bory, nephew to M. Beaujon at Paris. Arrival of the Marquis de la Fayette from Boston. News of prizes. The failure of the House of Besmarin tends to increase the prejudice against American connections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires a written testimonial from Franklin of the services he rendered to America; the great assistance which it will be to him in his approaching interview with the Minister.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending M. Panier as the best manufacturer of printing presses.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating Franklin on his appointment as Minister Plenipotentiary; impossible for Congress to have made a choice more gratifying to France.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on his appointment as Minister Plenipotentiary. The sincerity of their devotion to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received a letter from John Lotcher, master of the "Victoria," one of two Swedish ships sent to France to be examined; he reports his arrival at Bas Island and his having lost sight of the other ship, "Anna Louisa," in a fog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for the return of a certain sum of money placed with Franklin's bankers to the account of M. [Pierre] Colomb, who, however, never touched it. Desires to know if vessels sailing under the Genoese flag can trade freely with the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for the promised letter of recommendation; sends a packet for M. Gérard which he begs Franklin to forward.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking that M. Marin be informed of the day and hour when he (Le Roux) will read about a new, patriotic and disinterested institution.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects to call the next day and congratulate him on his appointment. Desires nothing more earnestly than to cultivate the harmony recommended in the Resolution of Congress; therefore, he will not, as he had intended, demand an explanation of Franklin's apparent concurrence with Mr. Deane in his outrageous abuse of himself.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending M. Panier as one of the ablest manufacturers of printing presses; his desire to set up his business in America. Hopes to have a talk with him at M. de la Blancherie's Assembly, which meets that day; congratulates him on his appointment as Minister Plenipotentiary.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will remain in London until the arrival of Mr. Hartley, to whom he will deliver Franklin's letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: After serving three years in the service of the United States, was taken prisoner by the English and brought to England; made his escape and went to Dunkirk where he was refused aid by Mr. Coffyn; started for Paris, but his money giving out and being unable to speak French, he was enlisted in the "regiment de Berwick"; desires to be sent back to Pennsylvania.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Having heard that Franklin is commissioned to have a gold sword made for the Marquis de la Fayette, recommends one of his friends who is willing to part with a magnificent sword, made for the late King of Portugal.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter for her brother, Mr. Alexander Gillon, of Charleston, who expects to be in Paris in a few days.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Franklin to be present at a meeting of the Royal Society of Medicine.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rectification of the mistake relative to Mr. Simcon Deane's goods.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notification of bills of exchange furnished to the States of Maryland, New York, Massachusetts-Bay and Delaware.
(In quadruplicate.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Saint-Pierre Dutalli (Dutaillis), Joseph-Nicolas. The Frigate Concord

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Officer and engineer in the American service; sends a copy of a letter written to M. de Sartine; his unfortunate experience and present imprisonment on board the frigate "Concord."
(In French.)

[Notes in English on back of Mss.] In M. de St. Pierre's letter to M. de Sartine, he confessed that, knowing how inhumanly the French prisoners were treated, he wrote a letter to the Governor of Jamaica proposing a plan for conquering Carolina and Georgia; encloses this plan and points out its palpable absurdity and the object for which it was written. His imprisonment at St. Domingo; later, sent a prisoner to France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a prospectus of their armament, and asking that Franklin and his friends should aid an enterprise, whose object is to insure commercial prosperity.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Durif de Cazaneuve, Capt. La Rochelle

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Commanded "Le Marquis de la Fayette," in the service of Messrs. Mease, Barclay, Caldwell and Co., of Philadelphia; taken prisoner by the English and detained three months at Halifax; exchanged by the Comte d'Estaing and arrived finally at La Rochelle; need of money; begs Franklin to accept a letter of exchange which was drawn on Messrs. Gruel, of Nantes, who refused to pay it.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for a letter of marque for the ship, "Mary Fearon." Concerning a letter from the President of the Navy Board at Boston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of his promise to redress his (Brutiere's) wrongs; was compelled by an American privateer to take on board his ship seven English prisoners, who consumed the major part of his supplies, and forced him to return to Dieppe; desires indemnification for his losses.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: [Joseph] Belton, an American, after boarding with him six months, left without paying; he promised to send the money upon his arrival in Paris whither he went to show Franklin a new kind of gun; begs Franklin's interest to obtain it for him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's letter of the 18th inst. in which he desires all the papers belonging to their department; reason why he declines to give up the few original papers in his possession relating to the transactions of their late joint Commission; if Congress orders it, will cede the point.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Obliged to have recourse to Franklin's bounty once again; the obduracy of his antagonist, which all the efforts of M. Turgot cannot soften, still subjects him to an unjust imprisonment; for want of a small sum of money, is unable to record his letters of naturalization. Has translated M. Dupont's Table of the Principles of Political Economy into English; desires to dedicate it to Franklin. His hope of retruning one day to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Influenced by their recommendation, given to Captains Marchant and Arnold, both of Boston, is ready to employ them on his vessel, the "Comte de Maurepas"; desires Franklin to send two commissions to them, under his care.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring that the enclosed pamphlet and letter may be forwarded to Mr. Silas Deane. Refers him to a certain page and line of his latest work for the quatrain referring to Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report just received from La Rochelle of the arrival there of a State vessel loaded with tobacco; no particulars as yet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Answers to certain questions about Mr. Mercier.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Answer to the French Ambassador returned as not satisfactory.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on his appointment as Minister Plenipotentiary, Begs him to interfere in the matter of exorbitant duties levied on some old furniture of his.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring the position of Consul to the United States in France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a native of Boston and a son of the late Captain Thompson who commanded the galley, " Experiment," in the service of Pennsylvania; gave up his commission in the army to take up commerce; his unsuccessful expedition to France; his present situation without money or friends; desires Franklin to procure him some honest employment and to help him out of his most pressing difficulties.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires Franklin to send the enclosed letter to Messrs. Wallisch and Hancock, as he is furnishing them with various article in his trade. Reports that the ship commanded by Captain Moses Grinnell, from Boston, and destined for Amsterdam, has arrived at Rotterdam.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to deliver to M. Necker the memoir, entitled, "Plan d'un nouvel Etablissement patriotique et désinteressé"; if this plan merits Franklin's approbation, has another copy for him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of their services in the army of the United States and their arrival in France in the "Boston" firgate commanded by Captain Tucker; were enticed into Berwick's French regiment, and having deserted in order to return to America, were retaken, punished and imprisoned; asks to be redeemed and sent back to the Continental troops.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Objects to completing his crew with French sailors. Repairs needed on the "Alliance"; enumerates the advantages of having her sheathed with copper; being thus equipped, sincerely believes there will be no frigate her equal in the world.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Before he set out for Marseilles, to take command of the "Flamand," he spoke to Mr. Deane concerning his compensation and Franklin approved of his views. Action of the Congress in relation thereto. Mr. Deane has been sitting in the Congress a long time, but nothing definite has yet been done. His monthly pay has been due since July 4th, last; has sold all his clothes and spent his cash, and has but nine guineas left.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Information about a certain clique of foreigners in France, enemies to America, who are kept informed by her false friends of all her adherents attempt to do.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Beaumont, Anne-Louise and Jean-Baptiste-Jacques Elie de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to dinner.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for the information of the arrival, at L'Orient, of the French ship " La Bergère," loaded with tobacco from Maryland; has written concerning their portion of the cargo.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reporting the appearance, off the coast, of the French frigate, "Courageuse," with an English six and twenty gun privateer in tow: the fight said to have been desperate; no particulars as yet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been promised the command of a privateer at Dunkirk; writes to ask for an American commission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking Franklin to procure American merchants the liberty of loading salt at Bordeaux, free of duty; complains that their ships are treated as stangers and obliged to pay duties accordingly.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Conti, Louis-François-Joseph de Bourbon, comte de la Marche and prince de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has arranged with Messrs. de Vergennes and sartine to give him the necessary passports for his stud-groom Riotto [Augustin Badran]; begs also for Franklin's passport; he goes to England to procure dogs and horses.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Claims his salary as well as his prize money due him during the service to Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Dr. Franklin to forward in his mail a letter to M. [Conrad Alexandre] Gérard [de Rayneval] which he sends.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the trial of the conspirators; urges again the advisability of sheating his vessel with copper; has not time to make an estimate of the expense of all the repairs needed; his reasons for objecting to exchange most of the conspirators and carry three or four of the wickedest to America for trail, as Franklin suggests.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to settle in America and asks his advice.
(In Itailan.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His Majesty's orders to remain in Paris without seeing a great number of acquaintances; thousand absurd rumors circulated about American affairs; happy to receive Franklin at his house.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Address presented to the States General and the Holland Assembly by a deputation of Rotterdam merchants, protesting against the wrong done them by the decree published in France; committee appointed to consult thereon with the Admiralty.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Business connected with his agency at Nantes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a copy of a letter received by Mr. Hartley from the Office for Sick and Wounded Seamen; Mr. Hartley's kind reception of him and his promise to send Franklin the earliest intelligence concerning an exchange of prisoners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has shared Franklin's discontent respecting the delay in the exchange of prisoners. Has received positive assurance that the first cartel-ship has left Spithead, on her passage to Plymouth, to take on board the first hundred. Has spoken to the Minister concerning Franklin's proposal to send Dr. Bancroft to expedite the exchange, but he thought it needless in so plain a business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring permission to leave the "Alliance," where he holds the position of purser, and go to Paris on his own business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering his service to supply Franklin with arms for the United States.
(In French.)
A.E. by Franklin. Obliged to the gentleman but has not at present anyorders of that kind to be executed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In reference to orders from the Navy Board of Boston, as to pay of the ship's company; encloses a copy. Expresses pleasure at the prospect of having the Honorable Mr. Adams as a passenger.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending the son of the French Consul at Rome for a consulship in that city.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Decision of the Admiralty already taken; understands that it is to be in accord with Amsterdam's wishes.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Obliged to draw on them to pay for the fitting out of the frigate, "Deane," and the armed brigantine, the "General Gates," now at St. Pierre; justifies this step; Congress indebted to him for a large sum; it is with the greatest difficulty he can support the weight of such heavy advances.
(Copy in duplicate.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Montaudoüin de la Touche, Jean-Gabriel. Nantes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating Franklin on his late appointment. Trusts that he has ceased to be troubled by the gout. Sorry to hear of the lack of success Comte d'Estaing has had. Introducing M. David de Morlaix.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating Franklin on his appointment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects to leave shortly for the West Indies with two or three friends; desires Franklin to lend them the protection of his name, should the fate of war make them prisoners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning Mr. Deane's inflammatory address, published in the newspapers of December 5th; the influence it exerted on the public; his reply to it; the abuse he met with not only from the people but from Congress. Justifies his attack on Mr. Deane from the papers in his possession; the pains he took not to involve Franklin in this affair; has had an exceeding rough time of it, but the tide of public sentiment has turned in his favor. Sent in his resignation of Secretary to the Committee of Foreign affairs.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: [Note on MS. by unknown hand. An unfair letter! Paine dismissed from his office as Secretary for using his position to publish the substance of secret despatches.]

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Mons, Samuel Stanley, baron and -----, baroness de. Altona

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking Franklin's influence with Congress that she may obtain possession of her property.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His admiration for America; desires to settle there, preferably in Pennsylvania, with several farmers who will go over under his direction; wishes information as to the price of land or whether it is granted gratis.
(In French.)

A. Dr. of answer by Benjamin Franklin. That the lands in Pennsylvania not yet granted all belong to the Proprietary, Mr. Penn. That he sells them for £5, sterling, the 100 acres. A price so low that probably the gentlemen would chuse rather to purchase than to accept them as a gift. That no lands are given to encourage strangers to settle in that province. A good climate, good air, good soil, good government, good laws and liberty have been sufficient encouragements without hiring inhabitants by other gifts; and all these he will meet with, besides an honest, virtuous people, who receive strangers with a sincere welcome and will respect his talents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notification of bills of exchange furnished the States of New Hampshire, New Jersey and Virginia.
(In triplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their ardent desire to see him again; his Mrs. Baldwin's regular Sunday entertainment. Hopes his son has received the letters of recommendation sent by Franklin. The profile he alluded to is 2 1/2 inches long, of the Royal Manufactory of Sauve; Miss Watkins promises to kiss it the moment it comes to hand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting instructions regarding the cargo of tobacco arrived from Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires Franklin to procure his son employment in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote him the year before, in June, with a request to forward to General Washington his letter concerning the whereabouts of Baron de Zedwitz, who owes him a large sum of money; desires to know if Franklin has received any information.
(In French.)
A. E. by Franklin. Sent his letter to America, but has heard nothing since.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote Franklin concerning the port duties charged on sundry articles shipped by the subjects of the United States. Asks him to obtain permission from the Minister for Messrs. Delap and himself to load the ship "Buckskin" with salt, free of duty. Offers to take any goods bound for Maryland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking Franklin to give his decision in the case of a prize brigladen with fish and oil, whose sale was stopped by the Judge of the Admiralty; need of haste owing to the perishable quality of the cargo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for his readiness to release him from the duties imposed on his furniture by the Farmers-General; sends a list of the articles involved. Pleased with the appointment of the Alliance to convey their ships to America. Arrival of "La Bergère" with a cargo of tobacco.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In February of the proceeding year, sent Franklin a letter to forward to General Daniel Roberdeau, Member of Congress in the United States; having received no answer, encloses another, which he begs may be sent by a safe conveyance.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The mystery so delicately mentioned in Franklin's favor of the 24th, he intended to explain much earlier; encloses a copy of the original paper; the subject was communicated to sundry members of Congress at the beginning of the war; after this misfortune of his life, was advised to retire incognito to America until the Admiralty Commission should arrive on the Island; everything changed by the revolution in America; appointments he received in the navy of the Colonies; his summary of his own character. Explains the affair of the pillage of Lord Selkirk's plate;1 his intention to restore it; believes Mr. Alexander to be his enemy; his indifference to spies. Congratulates Franklin on his appointment. Concerning the outfit of the "Poor Richard."

[Enclosure.] Account of the accidental killing of a mutinous sailor, by the master of West India ship [evidently John Paul Jones himself]; his actions, subsequent to this melancholy accident; reasons why he did not surrender himself for trial.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in The Independent, April 12, 1906, P. 833.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: 1 See also "John Paul Jones Commemoration at Annapolis, April 24, 1906.", Washington, 1907, p. 123 et seq.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News of the arrival of various ships from America. South Carolina perfectly secure from any attempt of the enemy. The ships at Nantes loaded and ready to sail.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Glad to hear of his welfare; neither of the drafts mentioned have appeared. Wishes they may live to meet when swords and spears are beat into plough shares and pruning hooks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has seen him at M. Marat's experiments; admired him from afar; sent him a prospectus of his work on Penal Laws, with a letter to which he has received no answer; asks his acceptance of a little work on the same subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin's acquaintance with the reasons for his coming to and remaining in Germany; is now about to return to America, unless Franklin can suggest some situation in which he can serve his country; if not, begs leave to carry Franklin's next despatches to Congress; this will perhaps entitle him to a free passage, an important point with him at present. Congratulates him on his appointment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: General run of articles ordered from America. Letter he wrote Mr. Lee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News of the arrival of certain vessels with their prizes. Lack of success among the French privateers from these ports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Well pleased at the disposition of the Swedish Court towards the American cause; has had several conferences with the Prime Minister and the king; believes that through Sweden, Russia might be wrought upon to change her attitude. Is about to leave for Amsterdam, whence he means to sail for America; desires Franklin to send him word if he can employ him in any adequate or useful manner. Hints at the likelihood of a certain family sowing seeds of discord in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Franklin to accept the enclosed drafts.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Observes by Franklin's favor of the 28th ult. that he is waiting to hear from Congress before granting his request.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Have a bill of exchange drawn on Franklin, for which they desire his signature.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Can do nothing respecting their Swedish prize until he receives Franklin's positive orders concerning the disposal of the prisoners and the refitting and manning of his ship.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a copy of his letter to Mr. Lee [of March 8] to which he has received no answer. Sorry to hear that M. Beaumarchais and the late Commissioners could not agree.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring him to frank the accompanying letter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Hamilton, of Ireland, a friend of liberty, and a lover of science. Has often wished for an opportunity to converse, or even to write with freedom on the subject of a scheme once entertained by Franklin in his favor. Is just printing off a volume of a new work of experiments in various branches of natural philosophy; promises to send him a copy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was disappointed when she heard Franklin's carriage go away. Had expected him to come in. Has been suffering from insomnia. Asks him to call soon.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Giving an account of his misfortunes since quitting St. Pierre, Martinique, in January, 1777, with a cagro bound for Charleston; twice he lost his vessel and twice he was imprisoned by the English; is now anxious to return to his wife and children at St. Pierre; sends Franklin a sum in silver of the United States and begs for an equivalent in French livres.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Solicits an answer to the letter he wrote some days before.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has heard of Franklin's success in curing several persons of the dropsy; begs to know the remedy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Related to Lord Arundel in England; has tried for six months, in vain, to obtain a position which will enable him to support his aged father; at present is only a common soldier; requests Franklin's protection; if this is refused, will be obliged to go to England and accept benefits from Lord Arundel.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter from Mr. Haywood, which will explain all the particulars relative to the small globe which Franklin was interested in.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pays Franklin extravagent compliments. Speaks of Franklin having introduced his grand-son to Voltaire, that he might say like Ovid did of Virgil; "Virgilium vidi."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to enter the American army and to spend the rest of his days in that country; hopes Franklin can procure him a commission.

[A.E. by Franklin.] Particularly instructed by Congress not to give encouragement to any persons desirous of serving in America as officers; abundance of officers in the country who cannot find employment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's two letters; being employed in moving to new lodgings, cannot answer them for some days.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends Franklin his work, La Legislation Orientale. France worthy of the honor the United States has conferred on them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects to return to America and will stop over at Paris to see her old friend. Her ability as a skillful modeller in wax; asks Franklin's opinion as to her chances of exercising this art in Paris; hopes to meet with the same success which she has achieved in London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of M. Sturler and M. de Neufville; account of the time he spent with the latter. Has put in order the plan of the future treaty [between Holland and America].
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has experienced the same trials as M. Marchant, whom Franklin sent to Dunkirk to command a frigate; begs for a letter of recommendation to some French agent at Nantes.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking that the passports and the needful papers may be sent. Begs that Thomas Wilkinson, formerly pilot of the "Drake," may be included in the first exchange of prisoners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on his appointment as Minister Plenipotentiary. Encloses two accounts which he begs him to settle.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Vergeel, Anthonius Albertus. Old Style. St. Petersburg

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to become a citizen of the United States. Gives personal sketch.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bust of Franklin is packed and ready; hardened it with wax, as desired; hopes it will arrive in good condition.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Laments the necessary interruption of their correspondence. Trusts he has recovered from his attack of gout. Their removal from Jermyn street to Bolton street; expects to spend the summer at Twyford. Her devotion to reading and drawing; has made no great progress in electricity since her instructor went away. Family news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a list of the ship's company showing the smallness of his crew. Surprised and wounded at Franklin's remarks about incurring expenses, etc. Delay in arranging for the disposal of the mutineers; difficulty of procuring the necessary articles for rigging his ship; repairs at present in progress; after the mutineers are on shore, provided the crew be strong enough, will proceed wherever Mr. Schweighauser directs, be the consequence what it may.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dined Mr. Adams. Convinced that M. de Fontevieux arrived safely in America the previous summer. M. Montieu's desire to have him take the "Franklin" frigate and one or two other vessels to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to be released from prison to enter the service of America.
(In French.)
(In triplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offered a chance by their friend "Saint Hutton" to get a letter to Franklin. Finds fault with him for remaining long enough in England to gain the love of some, and then quarreling with others to such fatal effect. Details all the news concerning his family.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Marigny, Charles-René-Louis, chevalier de Bernard de . Brest

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Doubts not that it was in great part due to Franklin that he obtained the position of captain in the navy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The box is ready to be removed whenever Franklin pleases; sends directions for unpacking it, in case it is sent to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's favor of the 13th relative to the few papers of their late joint Commission, remaining in his hands; is ready to give copies, sealed and authenticated, of all of them, but declines to relinquish the originals, which are necessary for the vindication of his character; that Mr. Adams gave up his papers, unasked, is not a case in point, he not being calumniated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers to supply Congress with the finest cloth for officers' uniforms.
(In French.)

A.E. by Franklin. Thanking them for offer, but, since the treaty between France and America, all such affairs are left to private merchants; wil communicate his letter to Mr. Jonathan Williams, of Nantes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Franklin to tea, to hear some music and play a game of chess.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers his services to America as a soldier, merchant or farmer; reasons for preferring the first-named; his qualifications, experience, etc.; conditions under which he is willing to go.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a list of the Americans detained at Calais as prisoners, with other details concerning them; if Franklin will send him an order for their release, will make a proper use of it; desires to know if he is to give them any money, as they are quite naked; has failed to find anyone by the name of Rousseaux, so cannot give the desired information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers his services to America in the quality of jurist, and desires Franklin's advice as to his chances of success.
(In Italian.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their intention to build a frigate for the destruction of France and America's common enemy; desires Franklin's permission to name the ship after him; wishes Franklin or some of his friends would take a part interest in her. Also interested in another expedition which consists in loading a merchant vessel at Marseilles for America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note of a mistake in giving two sets of bills of exchange the same numbers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notifying them of the issuance of the duplicate bills authorized by the Continental Congress February 14, 1779.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notification of the issuance of bills of exchange to the State of New Jersey.
(In triplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
